#Text=Wikinews interviews Christoph Bals of the NGO Germanwatch after conclusion of climate conference
#Text=Correction — February 25 , 2008
#Text=Translation problems from German to English , see Talk page .
#Text=Thursday , December 27 , 2007
#Text=A year ago I would have found the current outcome almost revolutionary . ...
#Text=A lot has been achieved , but the biggest hurdles are still in front of us .
#Text=— Christoph Bals , Senior Political Executive of Germanwatch

#Text=With the Climate Conference in Bali having come to a successful conclusion , Wikinews journalist Sean Heron interviewed Christoph Bals from the German NGO Germanwatch on his opinion of the outcome , and an outlook on the future negotiations .
#Text=Christoph is the Senior Political Executive of Germanwatch , Co-Author of the Climate protection-Index and did lobby work on Bali .
#Text=The interview
#Text=Introduction to Germanwatch
#Text=Wikinews : Could you explain what defines the organization Germanwatch and what your targets are ?
#Text=Christoph Bals :
#Text=Germanwatch is a non governmental organization ( NGO ) that has the environment and north south justice/fairness as its main topics .

#Text=We do n't actually execute any projects in the south , but lend issues that are of relevance to the south - the so called developing nations - a voice towards politics , the economy and on the financial market .
#Text=WN : Could you go into more specifics on what it is you do on climate change ?
#Text=CB
#Text=: Climate Change is one of our main topics .
#Text=Both the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and adaptation to climate change is important .
#Text=For these two issues we engage ourselves both with regard to Germany and the least developed countries ( LDCs ) .

#Text=We are intensively involved in national and international political processes , building up pressure on politicians and economic players and/or working constructively with them , depending on how greater achievements are to be made .
#Text=The Negotiations in Bali
#Text=WN : The next question , which is very much at hand , is of course how Germanwatch views the outcome of the negotiations ?
#Text=Have your expectations been fulfilled ?
#Text=CB
#Text=:
#Text=We have n't been able to write in the reduction targets that we would have needed .
#Text=But these targets can still be achieved in the negotiating framework that the Roadmap has put down .
#Text=The biggest obstacle here were the United States .
#Text=It wo n't be possible to agree to targets with this administration , but hopefully , in two years and with the next administration , we 'll be able to agree to the necessary global targets .

#Text=It is to be hoped for ... that a coalition of progressive industrial nations , least developed countries ... and newly industrialized countries - for example China , Mexico , South Africa , India - support this .
#Text=There were first signs for such a development in Bali .
#Text=— Christoph Bals
#Text=WN : Would you have expected this outcome yesterday ?
#Text=Or a year ago ?
#Text=CB
#Text=: A year ago I would have found the current outcome almost revolutionary .
#Text=Compared with my expectations before the negotiation it 's different though ; I then still had the hope that there would be more extensive progress at the end of this climate year .

#Text=If you look at the packages that have been agreed on : technology transfer and development , adaptation to climate change , financial mechanisms , forest protection ; then you can see that quite a substantial process has been started .
#Text=So a lot has been achieved , but the biggest hurdles are still in front of us .
